sites.name: Les Arènes de Nîmes
sites.description: This remarkably well-preserved Roman amphitheater, built around 70 AD, is one of the best-preserved in the world and the largest in France. With a capacity of 24,000 spectators, it hosted gladiatorial contests and continues to host bullfights, concerts, and cultural events. The elliptical structure features 60 arches and impressive stonework that showcases Roman engineering excellence.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Summer brings bullfighting festivals and concerts. Spring and autumn offer pleasant weather for exploration. Winter visits are quieter with fewer crowds.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking recommended for events and guided tours. Audio guides available in multiple languages. Combined tickets available with other Roman sites.

sites.name: Maison Carrée
sites.description: This perfectly preserved Roman temple, built between 16-20 BC, is one of the finest examples of Roman architecture in the world. Originally dedicated to the grandsons of Emperor Augustus, its Corinthian columns and elegant proportions have inspired architects for centuries, including Thomas Jefferson who used it as a model for the Virginia State Capitol.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful lighting in morning hours. The temple is illuminated at night year-round. Interior exhibitions change seasonally.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Audio-visual presentation inside explains the temple's history. Combined tickets available with other Roman sites.

sites.name: Tour Magne
sites.description: This 32-meter high Roman tower, built in 15 BC, stands on the highest point of the city and offers spectacular panoramic views of Nîmes and the surrounding countryside. Originally part of the Roman city walls, it was used as a watchtower and landmark for travelers approaching the city.
sites.seasonal_notes: Best visited during golden hour for photography. Summer evenings offer extended opening hours. Winter visits are quieter but weather-dependent.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Climb the spiral staircase for the best views. Combined tickets available with other Roman sites.

sites.name: Jardin de la Fontaine
sites.description: Created in 1745, this beautiful French formal garden is built around the ancient Roman spring that gave Nîmes its name. The garden features elegant terraces, fountains, statues, and the remains of the Roman Temple of Diana. It's a perfect blend of 18th-century landscaping and ancient Roman heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Spring brings magnificent blooms and fountains. Summer features evening illuminations. Autumn offers beautiful foliage colors. Winter visits are peaceful but some fountains may be off.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free guided tours available on weekends during summer. The garden connects to the Tour Magne.

sites.name: Cathédrale Notre-Dame-et-Saint-Castor
sites.description: This Romanesque cathedral, built in the 17th century on the site of an earlier church, features a mix of architectural styles reflecting Nîmes' long history. The interior houses beautiful stained glass windows, a historic organ, and religious artifacts. The cathedral stands in the heart of the old town near the Roman sites.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful lighting in mornings when sun shines through the stained glass. Special religious services during Easter and Christmas. Organ concerts occasionally held.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Respect quiet during services. Check schedule for special events and concerts.

sites.name: Musée de la Romanité
sites.description: This modern museum, opened in 2018, houses an impressive collection of Roman artifacts discovered in and around Nîmes. The contemporary building contrasts beautifully with the ancient Roman sites and features interactive exhibits, mosaics, sculptures, and a rooftop garden with views of the amphitheater.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with air conditioning in summer. Special exhibitions rotate seasonally. Less crowded on weekday afternoons.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking recommended during peak season. Audio guides available in multiple languages. Combined tickets available with Roman sites.

sites.name: Place du Marché
sites.description: This lively square in the heart of the old town hosts the daily market and is surrounded by historic buildings, cafés, and restaurants. The market offers fresh local produce, regional specialties, and a perfect opportunity to experience daily life in Nîmes. The square is particularly atmospheric in the morning.
sites.seasonal_notes: Market operates daily except Mondays. Summer brings outdoor dining and evening atmosphere. Winter markets focus on seasonal produce and local specialties.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Come early for the best selection. Many vendors accept cards but cash is preferred.

sites.name: Porte d'Auguste
sites.description: This Roman gate, built around 16-15 BC, was one of the main entrances to the ancient city of Nemausus. Although partially destroyed, it still stands as a testament to Roman urban planning and engineering. The gate features decorative elements and inscriptions that provide insight into Roman Nîmes.
sites.seasonal_notes: Visible year-round. Best photographed in morning light. The surrounding area is particularly pleasant in spring and autumn.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free to view from the street. Located near the train station and easily accessible.

sites.name: Carré d'Art
sites.description: This contemporary art museum, designed by British architect Norman Foster, houses a collection of modern and contemporary art. The building's glass façade reflects the ancient Roman sites across the square, creating a fascinating dialogue between ancient and modern architecture.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with air conditioning. Special exhibitions rotate seasonally. The rooftop café offers great views of the Roman sites.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required for general admission. Check website for special exhibitions and events.

sites.name: Esplanade Charles de Gaulle
sites.description: This large public square connects the old town with the newer parts of the city and offers excellent views of the Roman amphitheater. The square is lined with cafés, restaurants, and shops, making it a perfect place to relax and soak in the atmosphere of Nîmes.
sites.seasonal_notes: Lively throughout the year. Summer evenings feature outdoor dining and street performers. The square is beautifully decorated during Christmas season.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Many restaurants offer outdoor seating in good weather. Popular spot for people-watching.

sites.name: Temple de Diane
sites.description: Located in the Jardin de la Fontaine, these Roman temple ruins date from the 2nd century AD and were likely dedicated to the goddess Diana. Although partially destroyed, the remaining structure gives visitors a sense of the temple's original grandeur and Roman religious practices.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round through the Jardin de la Fontaine. Best visited in morning light for photography. Spring and autumn offer pleasant weather for exploration.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free to view. Located within the Jardin de la Fontaine.

sites.name: Quartier des Halles
sites.description: This charming historic district features narrow medieval streets, traditional shops, and authentic local atmosphere. The area is known for its traditional crafts, local boutiques, and historic architecture that provides a contrast to the Roman sites and shows Nîmes' medieval heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round. Summer brings outdoor café culture. Winter offers cozy indoor shopping experiences. The district is particularly atmospheric in the evening.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Best explored on foot. Many shops close on Sundays and Monday mornings.

sites.name: Parc des Costières
sites.description: This large public park on the outskirts of Nîmes offers walking trails, picnic areas, and beautiful views of the city and surrounding countryside. The park is popular with locals for outdoor activities and provides a peaceful escape from the busy city center.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful in spring with wildflowers. Summer offers shade and cooler temperatures. Autumn brings beautiful foliage colors. Winter visits are peaceful but weather-dependent.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free access at all times. Parking available. Popular for jogging and cycling.

sites.name: Musée du Vieux Nîmes
sites.description: This museum, housed in a beautiful 17th-century building, showcases the history and traditions of Nîmes through exhibits on local crafts, traditional costumes, and daily life throughout the centuries. The collection provides insight into how Nîmes evolved from a Roman city to a modern French town.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round except Mondays. Air conditioned in summer. Special exhibitions related to local history and traditions.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Free guided tours available on weekends. Audio guides available in French and English.

sites.name: Chapelle des Jésuites
sites.description: This 17th-century Jesuit chapel features beautiful Baroque architecture and interior decoration. The church is known for its ornate altarpiece, painted ceiling, and religious artwork that reflects the artistic and religious heritage of Nîmes during the Counter-Reformation period.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round for religious services and visitors. Beautiful lighting in morning hours. Occasional concerts and cultural events.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Respect quiet during services. Check schedule for special events and concerts.

sites.name: Place de l'Horloge
sites.description: This charming square in the old town features a historic clock tower and is surrounded by traditional buildings and cafés. The square is a perfect place to experience the authentic atmosphere of Nîmes and enjoy a coffee while watching local life unfold.
sites.seasonal_notes: Lively throughout the year. Summer brings outdoor dining and street life. Winter offers cozy indoor café experiences. The square is particularly atmospheric in the evening.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Many cafés offer outdoor seating in good weather. Popular spot for people-watching and photography.

sites.name: Canal de la Fontaine
sites.description: This historic canal, built in the 18th century, carries water from the Roman spring through the city center. The canal is lined with walking paths and offers a peaceful route for exploring the city. It's particularly beautiful in the evening when illuminated.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round. Spring brings fresh greenery along the banks. Summer evenings feature pleasant walks and cooling breezes. Autumn offers beautiful foliage colors.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free access at all times. Popular for evening strolls and photography.
